isis.stitle: TSI 94-14-03 - Procedures for Welding a Transverse Torque Rod Bracket to a Rear Axle

subjectgroup.subject: Procedures for Welding a Transverse Torque Rod Bracket to a Rear Axle

lev1.para: To provide satisfactory service life, the procedure for welding transverse torque rods to rear axle housings must be followed. The following welding information will aid a welder in providing a commercial quality weld for truck applications.

lev1.title: WELDER CERTIFICATION
lev1.para: All welding on axle housings must be done by welders certified by an independent testing laboratory to meet the requirements of AWS D1.1 Structural Welding Code.

warning.para: Invisible ultraviolet and infrared rays emitted in welding can injure unprotected eyes and skin. Protection such as welder's helmet with dark colored filter lenses of the proper density must be used. GTAW or TIG welding will produce intense radiation, therefore, filter plate lenses of the deepest shade providing adequate visibility are recommended. It is strongly recommended that persons working in the weld area wear flash safety goggles. Also wear protective clothing.

lev1.title: SURFACE PREPARATION
lev1.para: Weld joints must be free from contamination, such as moisture, lubricants and rust. Paint must be removed since it will adversely affect the weld quality.

lev1.title: WELD JOINT FIT-UP
lev1.para: A slight grind to fit condition may exist between the housing and bracket due to axle housing and bracket tolerances. Grind the bracket to fit ( Figure 1). The bracket should fit-up as close as possible to avoid excessive welding.

lev1.title: WELD LENGTHS
lev1.para: The effective weld length shall not include skips, off location welds and/or other conditions defined in the WELD QUALITY section of this letter.

lev1.title: WELD LOCATION
lev1.para: All welds should be centered laterally in the joint in a manner to insure fusion between the parts being joined. Portions of the weld which are undersize, or do not meet the minimum requirements for weld quality (undercut, porosity, craters) shall be considered as skips and are not considered in the weld length.

lev1.title: WELD LEG SIZE
lev1.para: The minimum weld leg has to be at least as thick as the minimum thickness of the thinnest member of the bracket.

lev1.title: THROAT THICKNESS
lev1.para: The minimum throat thickness of fillet welds are to be equal to 60% of the shortest weld leg size. Maximum throat thickness is to be limited to 100% of the longest leg size ( Figure 2).

lev1.title: DEFINITIONS
lev1.para: The welding terms shall be interpreted in accordance with the definitions given in AWS - Weld (ANSI/AWS A2.4 latest issue).

lev1.title: SYMBOLS
lev1.para: Welding symbols shall be interpreted in accordance with AWS Standard Welding Symbols (ANSI/AWS A2.4 latest issue).

lev1.title: WELD QUALITY
lev1.para: Unless otherwise specified, the following characteristics shall be permitted. No more than one of these characteristics shall be permitted in the weld if the any other characteristic is at the maximum limit.

lev2.title: Craters
lev2.para: Unfilled craters are not considered part of the effective weld length, and are therefore limited by the length of the weld tolerance for gaps. They can be properly filled and counted in the weld length.

lev2.title: Cracks and Burn-through
lev2.para: Cracks in the weld and holes burned through the base stock will not be permitted.

lev3.title: Frequency
lev3.para: No more than four (4) significant pores shall be permitted in any 1 inch (25 mm) of weld length with the average limited to one (1) per 1 inch (25 mm) of weld length.

lev3.title: Severity
lev3.para: The maximum diameter of the pores shall be 1/16 inch (1.6 mm) and shall be spaced at least 1/16 inch (1.6 mm) apart.
Pores must be larger than 1/64 inch (0.4 mm) in diameter to be considered significant. Porosity shall not be permitted in any weld specified as oil tight.

lev2.title: Inclusions
lev2.para: Non-metallic inclusions shall be considered and judged as a gap.

lev1.title: WELDING RECOMMENDATIONS
lev1.para: The welding rod used shall produce a minimum tensile strength of 70,000 psi using an all-weld-metal test sample tested in accordance with AWS B4.0. Typical processes and electrodes which meet this requirement are as follows:

lev2.title: Process

item.para: Shielded metal-arc welding of carbon low alloy steels.
Gas metal-arc welding of carbon and low alloy steels.
Submerged arc welding of mild and low alloy steels.

lev2.para: Use the voltage and amperage recommended by the electrode manufacturer. This will provide the best fusion and strongest weld.

Do not "test the arc" on the housing. Deposit the required amount of metal with the least number of passes - one pass is preferred. Where a second pass is required, thoroughly remove the slag from the weld between passes.

On brackets that require welding all around, distortion and stress can be further controlled by welding on opposite sides of the bracket alternately. Figure 3 shows the tack welding sequence. Tack welds must be cleaned prior to final welding.

Figure 4 shows the sequence and direction of the final weld. Start weld at each end of bracket and work toward middle of bracket. Remove the slag from the weld. Cover the tack welds with the final welds.
There is a notch in the end of the transverse torque rod bracket for use as a moisture drain. Do not weld in the area of the notch ( Figure 5).
If information on welding locations of transverse rods is required, call 1-800-44TRUCK.
